case_vignette: a previously healthy 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 3-day history of progressive rash. the rash started on his face and now involves the entire body. for the past week, he has had a cough and a runny nose. he is visiting from the philippines with his family. he is in first grade and spends his afternoons at an after-school child care program. immunization records are not available. his temperature is 39.5°c (103°f), pulse is 115/min, and blood pressure is 105/66 mm hg. examination shows generalized lymphadenopathy. there is an erythematous maculopapular, blanching, and partially confluent exanthem on his entire body. the remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
question: which  is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

I've had a rash that started on my face and now covers my entire body, along with a cough and a runny nose for the past week. My temperature is also high at 39.5°C (103°F).
Are there any white spots inside your mouth or around your lips?
No, there are no white spots inside my mouth or around my lips mentioned.
Have you been vaccinated for measles?
My immunization records are not available.
Has anyone around you had similar symptoms recently?
It’s not mentioned if anyone around me has had similar symptoms recently.
**Final Diagnosis:** Measles
